Basically Medieval Dynasty, but more dangerous. Instead of bandits being a rare and random thing you might have the misfortune to run into, at least the beginning of the game (where I still am) largely revolves around eliminating the many camps of bandits who are terrorizing the region. But other than that, it's still a game of playing as a Medieval peasant who walks around picking up sticks and rocks and edible things to try to survive and build a settlement. Whereas the devs of Medieval Dynasty have been hinting at some kind of mystery to be solved in the Oxbow but never got around to delivering, Bellwright is very plot-driven. Whereas the whole objective in Medieval Dynasty is just to have a kid (not that hard, and the game plateaus after that), Bellwright also has you arriving as a homeless orphan unraveling a history of a crime against a loved one, but leads to you liberating villages and commanding an army. Bit more exciting than just hunting the same bear once every season.
It has its glitches and frustrations but nothing that cannot be fixed with mod's until the dev's decide to include features in the game... Hours of fun and even some replayability

Bellwright — Review

Bellwright feels like someone spliced a village-builder’s brain onto a first-person fighter’s body. If Kingdom Come: Deliverance had a baby with Manor Lords, you’d get this: a gritty, hands-on medieval rebellion where you plan production chains, place buildings, and then personally wade into the mud with sword and bow.

What clicked for me
Liberating villages feeds directly into your city-building loop: free a settlement, recruit townsfolk, assign jobs, and watch your outposts hum while you push the frontier. It’s satisfying how the macro (roads, logistics, tech tiers) feeds the micro (your loadout, your squad). The directional combat has weight; archery especially feels great, and taking on groups carelessly will punish you—so you learn to block, flank, command, and pick shots.

The builder side
Progression is clear and rewarding—new buildings, better gear, more efficient production—and the map is big enough to keep that expansion itch going. Co-op is a natural fit: splitting roles between “mayor” and “marshal” makes the midgame sing.

Still Early Access (and evolving fast)
It’s still in Early Access, so expect occasional bugs, balance swings, and systems that feel mid-construction. The bright side is active development and steady patching, with more content on the horizon.

Verdict
I love the hybrid here. Bellwright nails that loop where your settlement empowers your sword-arm—and your victories feed your settlement. If the KCD × Manor Lords pitch speaks to you and you’re fine with Early Access edges, this is absolutely worth your time right now.

It's a fine premise, but even in spite of lowering my expectations for its Early Access status, I was not hooked on anything. If anything, the pace of gathering was sluggish, and especially the state of combat seemed extremely lackluster at the start, with the quest to kill the 3 wolves. With no way to actually determine which of the four directions even block, or if blocking even negated damage or simply reduced it by some negligible amount with the beginner axe and wooden spear, I was quickly chunked down and had to actually just straight up dps race it, and lost. This could be genuine skill issue on my part, but there weren't really any memorable tutorials for combat.

If I could suggest a few things, it would be:
1. Adding a separate button to enter a 'combat stance' of sorts. Trying to left click to build with an axe in hand is frustrating when you just swing randomly. At the same time, this could add depth to NPC interaction and reaction. Like maybe some traders would not immediately refuse you service for having a 'weapon in hand', but some might have differing prices based on an intimidation factor, at the cost of negatively impacting your social status or 'fame'; this idea might need a bit of workshopping, though, and could easily become scope creep. Simply focusing on a separate state of merely 'holding' a weapon/tool as opposed to intending to use said implement in combat is enough.
2. Add fists as a 'weapon', since there will be a separate state for combat and non-combat.
3. Add an interrupting segment to the first main quest when you enter the village to talk to the elder, where you find a drunk by the initial gate the player is intended to enter from (thus allowing them to walk around if they don't wish to deal with this), who insults the player and starts a confrontation, where combat (and directional attacking/blocking) can be more intuitively taught to the player.

The game wasn't aggressively unfun, and there's not too many good city/colony building games with emphasis on personal involvement/development that I could find, more of a RimWorld player myself, but there's really not a lot in this Early Access to keep playing for me personally.

I want to really rave about this game. 

But in the current state... I can't.

There's a level of obtuseness in some of the design decisions.. some of which you can bypass with mods. 

The good.
There's a real sense of progression. Each win feels meaningful. 

Crafting your own fast travel points - big win tbh..

The bad (much longer list)
The game is punishing. There's no way to know that you have limited yourself without failing... over and over. 
Camp placement is a massive thing. Place it wrong and you can't progress - your NPCs/townfolk can't move to the north side of the map, but you can. You can build out there too but there's no indicators this will be a problem until you've committed your resources. Just dumb design choices. 

Tech tree - on the one hand, it feels like it fits. On the other, you can't research tech because your townsfolk/followers are meant to do this. This makes sense since some of the tech unlocks range upwards of 15-20 minutes, in real time. For a single player focused game, that design decision is DUMB. Make your follower/townsfolk mechanic actually work if you're going in this direction. 

The follower/townsfolk tasking - non intuitive and unfriendly. Reddit is full of posts from players who had massive issues getting their townsfolk to gather/research/craft items.. even when you've met the resource requirements. It is poorly explained and the guidance sucks. 

The fixed camera - there's no first person perspective on this and you can't scale out your FOV either. You are locked into looking over your avatar's shoulder the whole way. 

Combat is janky. That's fine. this is early access but it gets old fast. 

The story line - main questline has potential - typical revenge/clear your name fare. Needs more polish - again.. Early Access.

Side quests - the game is full of fetch quests/clear quests. There aren't any dungeons. 

The inventory management is abysmal. There's no sort function. There's no weight mechanic. Instead items take up volume in your inventory. That's fine. What is a major gripe is that you can't optimise your inventory in any reasonable way. A log takes up 9 squares - sure, whatever. But the game doesn't let you organise your allotment of space (30 squares = 6 columns x 5 rows) to move things around. So you get instances where you should be able to fit 2 logs (18 squares) in the first 3 rows and have two empty rows to fit items. But if you already have items that you're carrying, the game will only fit one log and prevent you from making room for the second. Requiring mods to give you unlimited volume to get around this is DUMB. 

Some double handed items take up more volume that others which is also DUMB. (Shovel is 6 squares. A bow is 3.)

Building - there's no fast disassemble option. Instead as your buildings go higher in tier, you have to dismantle, piece by piece. This becomes necessary because the game lets you build buildings that you can't enter once they're built because the terrain has a gentle slope. No crouch means you can't enter under the doorframe and your townsfolk don't break buildings down, they just build them. So it's on you to break it down or move it. At tier 1 - no problem. At tier 2 - it took 8 in game hours to move a Cabin..

The game has been out for a year now, they're still working on it (promising) but it still needs work. 

My advice - wait for more content and a sale. Then mod it to make your life easier.

This one is a weird one for me.

First and foremost: the AI voices. Stop it. Get rid of them. The game would IMMEDIATELY sound better, and you would lose nothing.

Second: Setting priorities for your villagers is aight, feels like Rimworld. UNLIKE Rimworld, however, your villagers are the slowest goddamn snails I've ever seen. God forbid you dismiss an armed party anywhere beyond 100 meters from your town, you'll be waiting til the heat death of the universe before they finally get back home to work.

Third: Building your buildings is pretty neat. Problem is as soon as you hit "Village Hall", it ain't worth it. It really really sucks. I get that it's supposed to feel like you're building every piece, but when you are actually 'building' every single piece it becomes tedious, boring. "Oh you can have your villagers do it!" Yeah, if I want to wait an unreasonable amount of time for it to be done. Let's not forget, they're SLOW. At EVERYTHING. It takes them over twice as long as it would take you to do it yourself, and that's with multiple villagers working at once.

Fourth: Seasons are a fun idea, given how impactful winter is for such an old society. Problem is you experience a full year in about 8 in-game days. Winter isn't anywhere near long enough to matter in any capacity. The other seasons aren't long enough to make it even feel like you're trying to prepare for winter. The seasons may as well not exist and the gameplay wouldn't change at all.

Fifth: The writing. Some of these quests feel like they were written by AI. And by 'some' I really mean 'most'. You could have the quests actually be engaging, we have the ability to command a small party of adventurers, and yet most quests are 'lol go make/fetch this for me' or similar. Not that it matters a whole lot, the pathfinding is a joke. If you have a small ankle-high wall somewhere, you can cheese any enemy.

Getting a non-awful amount of experience for what you decide to do, or what your villagers do. The books are just another bit of micro that doesn't need to be there. Watch some YouTube coverage of the game or something. Or go play Rimworld.

I want to really rave about this game. 

But in the current state... I can't.

There's a level of obtuseness in some of the design decisions.. some of which you can bypass with mods. 

The good.
There's a real sense of progression. Each win feels meaningful. 

Crafting your own fast travel points - big win tbh..

The bad (much longer list)
The game is punishing. There's no way to know that you have limited yourself without failing... over and over. 
Camp placement is a massive thing. Place it wrong and you can't progress - your NPCs/townfolk can't move to the north side of the map, but you can. You can build out there too but there's no indicators this will be a problem until you've committed your resources. Just dumb design choices. 

Tech tree - on the one hand, it feels like it fits. On the other, you can't research tech because your townsfolk/followers are meant to do this. This makes sense since some of the tech unlocks range upwards of 15-20 minutes, in real time. For a single player focused game, that design decision is DUMB. Make your follower/townsfolk mechanic actually work if you're going in this direction. 

The follower/townsfolk tasking - non intuitive and unfriendly. Reddit is full of posts from players who had massive issues getting their townsfolk to gather/research/craft items.. even when you've met the resource requirements. It is poorly explained and the guidance sucks. 

The fixed camera - there's no first person perspective on this and you can't scale out your FOV either. You are locked into looking over your avatar's shoulder the whole way. 

Combat is janky. That's fine. this is early access but it gets old fast. 

The story line - main questline has potential - typical revenge/clear your name fare. Needs more polish - again.. Early Access.

Side quests - the game is full of fetch quests/clear quests. There aren't any dungeons. 

The inventory management is abysmal. There's no sort function. There's no weight mechanic. Instead items take up volume in your inventory. That's fine. What is a major gripe is that you can't optimise your inventory in any reasonable way. A log takes up 9 squares - sure, whatever. But the game doesn't let you organise your allotment of space (30 squares = 6 columns x 5 rows) to move things around. So you get instances where you should be able to fit 2 logs (18 squares) in the first 3 rows and have two empty rows to fit items. But if you already have items that you're carrying, the game will only fit one log and prevent you from making room for the second. Requiring mods to give you unlimited volume to get around this is DUMB. 

Some double handed items take up more volume that others which is also DUMB. (Shovel is 6 squares. A bow is 3.)

Building - there's no fast disassemble option. Instead as your buildings go higher in tier, you have to dismantle, piece by piece. This becomes necessary because the game lets you build buildings that you can't enter once they're built because the terrain has a gentle slope. No crouch means you can't enter under the doorframe and your townsfolk don't break buildings down, they just build them. So it's on you to break it down or move it. At tier 1 - no problem. At tier 2 - it took 8 in game hours to move a Cabin..

The game has been out for a year now, they're still working on it (promising) but it still needs work. 

My advice - wait for more content and a sale. Then mod it to make your life easier.

This one is a weird one for me.

For every good thing it has, it has some design decision that's just... annoying. Or worse.

First and foremost: the AI voices. Stop it. Get rid of them. The game would IMMEDIATELY sound better, and you would lose nothing.

Second: Setting priorities for your villagers is aight, feels like Rimworld. UNLIKE Rimworld, however, your villagers are the slowest goddamn snails I've ever seen. God forbid you dismiss an armed party anywhere beyond 100 meters from your town, you'll be waiting til the heat death of the universe before they finally get back home to work.

Third: Building your buildings is pretty neat. Problem is as soon as you hit "Village Hall", it ain't worth it. It really really sucks. I get that it's supposed to feel like you're building every piece, but when you are actually 'building' every single piece it becomes tedious, boring. "Oh you can have your villagers do it!" Yeah, if I want to wait an unreasonable amount of time for it to be done. Let's not forget, they're SLOW. At EVERYTHING. It takes them over twice as long as it would take you to do it yourself, and that's with multiple villagers working at once.

Fourth: Seasons are a fun idea, given how impactful winter is for such an old society. Problem is you experience a full year in about 8 in-game days. Winter isn't anywhere near long enough to matter in any capacity. The other seasons aren't long enough to make it even feel like you're trying to prepare for winter. The seasons may as well not exist and the gameplay wouldn't change at all.

Fifth: The writing. Some of these quests feel like they were written by AI. And by 'some' I really mean 'most'. You could have the quests actually be engaging, we have the ability to command a small party of adventurers, and yet most quests are 'lol go make/fetch this for me' or similar. It's boring, it only takes away from actually doing something relatively engaging; growing my town.

Sixth: I mentioned that you can command a small group of adventurers, and it's true. Problem is they're still dumb as shit. They won't arm themselves if you take them along as companions, none of your villagers will equip armor that's better than their rags, you NEED to micromanage this nonsense. Not that it matters a whole lot, the pathfinding is a joke. If you have a small ankle-high wall somewhere, you can cheese any enemy.

Seventh: Skill books. They exist. Couldn't tell you why they exist. "They provide a buff to the chosen skill's experience!" You know what else would do that? Getting a non-awful amount of experience for what you decide to do, or what your villagers do. The books are just another bit of micro that doesn't need to be there. It feels like the books were a band-aid solution to "wow experience gains are low/slow" when it would have been far more effective to just increase exp gains across the board. The 30+minute 'reading' time is also a joke, which defeats the purpose of even collecting the books.

Basically, as I mentioned above, the devs had neat ideas, but for every neat idea they did something else that ruins the experience. Not much has changed since Early Access release either. All of my gripes existed on day one, and nothing has changed on either of these points in over a year. I'd stay away until you see some real progress. Watch some YouTube coverage of the game or something. Or go play Rimworld.

I write in early access:  

I find the game to be incredibly frustrating, unclear, and most importantly, unfair to the player. 
That said, I still do play it - it gets better after 12 to 18 hours, which isn't much of a selling point, in my opinion.

What's good:  A large, beautiful map.  A sense of surviving.  A slow sense of growth and overcoming enemies.

What's bad:  Frustratingly difficult start, where misplacement of your first home can cause hours of insta-death grief from baddies.  No clear understanding of the natural world.  Clearly trees sprout and animals return each spring, but how do I help that along?

I got stuck in a loop where I misplaced my town, was getting hit by bandits, boars, and wolves.  I had an NPC to help me get weapons, but he was in constant time-out due to his eternal return of death by bandits, wolves, and boars.  I spent hours trying to save him.  Turned out, I was just in a bad spot - who knew?  

Then we chopped down some trees.  They were kinda growing back.  There were some other tress to my north, but no one ever survived. I'd head there and get one-shot killed.  My pal would head up there and get one-shot killed.  Clearly, he became disgruntled.  I wanted to hire some beggars, but because I had been killed so many times, I had no clout with the town.  No one else would move in with me because I had so little clout.

F-it.  Restart.  Same dang thing happened again.  Stuck in a loop of loss.

F-it 3rd time.  Base in a better spot, fewer attacks, tweaked the game to give me buffs.  Still get killed over and over and over.  NPCs still on constant time-out.  I started to get some weapons and armor and did defeat a handful of small bandit troops, but they still keep coming it.

That said, once I could finally defeat the small bandit troops I felt great.  I had that Dark Souls high.  But, the same pattern happened again.  But that little Dark Souls high kept me going for a dozen hours. 

Would I recommend the game?  Not in its current state.  But there is a game in there.
